clusters.title: ‘My ex is trying to kill me’: The 89-second call for help moments before alleged murder
clusters.neutral_headline: Sydney Woman's Final Call Before Alleged Murder
bullet_summary: Reported by The Age, ABC Just In, 9News

items.title: ‘My ex is trying to kill me’: The 89-second call for help moments before alleged murder
items.standfirst: Tatiana Dokhotaru allegedly made a desperate plea for help moments before Danny Zayat took her phone off her, threw it off her apartment balcony and killed her, a court has heard.
items.content: Tatiana Dokhotaru allegedly made a desperate plea for help moments before Danny Zayat took her phone off her, threw it off her apartment balcony and killed her, a court has heard.

items.title: 'He's trying to kill me': Sydney woman's final triple-0 call
items.standfirst: Danny Zayat has pleaded not guilty over the alleged murder of his former partner Tatiana Dokhotaru on May 26, 2023, in a high-rise complex in Sydney's south-west.
items.content: Danny Zayat has pleaded not guilty over the alleged murder of his former partner Tatiana Dokhotaru on May 26, 2023, in a high-rise complex in Sydney's south-west.

items.title: Slain Sydney woman's last call about ex 'trying to kill me'
items.standfirst: Tatiana Dokhotaru was killed in her 22nd-floor apartment in southwest Sydney late at night on May 26, 2023.
items.content: In a triple-zero call shortly before her death, a fearful woman said her violent, former partner was at her home trying to kill her and steal her money.Tatiana Dokhotaru was killed in her 22nd-floor apartment in southwest Sydney late at night on May 26, 2023.Her ex-partner Danny Zayat, 30, has pleaded not guilty to her murder and faced the first day of a NSW Supreme Court jury trial on Monday.READ MORE: Shock sweeping changes to super for millions of Australians revealedJurors heard of the 89-second call that Ms Dokhotaru made to triple zero shortly before she was allegedly murdered."Yes, hi. My ex-boyfriend's here and he's trying to kill me," she told the operator.On a recording of the call, the pair could be heard arguing about money, crown prosecutor Alex Morris said.Dokhotaru told the operator she was being bashed and that Zayat was stealing her money, he said.She provided the address of her apartment in the Sydney suburb of Liverpool before the call ended, the jury heard.The Crown alleges Zayat took the phone, ended the call and then threw the device off the unit's high-rise balcony.READ MORE: Millions of Aussies could cop fines up to $1650 if they miss this tax return deadlineIt was never recovered, the court was told.Zayat is accused of murdering Dokhotaru sometime in the next hour.He allegedly did so through one or more blows to the head, or by hitting her on the head and pushing her over, causing a head injury.The intention was either to kill or inflict really serious bodily harm to his ex-partner, Mr Morris said.Prosecutors have brought an alternative charge of manslaughter against Zayat if the charge of murder cannot be proven beyond reasonable doubt.The trial continues.Support is available from the National Sexual Assault, Domestic and Family Violence Counselling Service at 1800RESPECT (1800 737 732).Kids Helpline 1800 55 1800.

ai_summary: Tatiana Dokhotaru made a desperate call for help before her death.
Danny Zayat is accused of throwing her phone and killing her.
Zayat has pleaded not guilty to the alleged murder.
The incident occurred in a high-rise apartment in Sydney.
The court heard the details of the 89-second call.

items.title: University of Sydney argues academic’s article not racist against Jewish people as ‘Zionism is a political concept’
items.standfirst: Case taken by academics against two colleagues and the university is considered a major test case for hate speech in AustraliaFollow our Australia news live blog for latest updatesGet our breaking news email, free app or daily news podcastThe University of Sydney has argued that an article written by a staff member that criticises Zionism was not racist against Jewish people because “Zionism is, at its core, a political concept”.The argument was heard in the federal court on Monday as part of a racial discrimination case taken by academics against two of their colleagues and the university, in what is being considered a major test case for hate speech in Australia. clusters.title: Sydney dentist denies claims patients potentially exposed to HIV
clusters.neutral_headline: Sydney Dentist Faces Claims of Infection Control Breaches

items.title: Sydney dentist denies claims patients potentially exposed to HIV
items.standfirst: Safuan Hasic, also known as Steven Hasic, has been barred from practising after breaching infection control standards at his Mortdale dentistry practice.
items.content: Safuan Hasic, also known as Steven Hasic, has been barred from practising after breaching infection control standards at his Mortdale dentistry practice.

items.title: Warning for patients of a Sydney dentist amid 'infection control breaches'
items.standfirst: Patients of a dentist in Sydney's south are being urged to get tested for blood borne viruses due to infection control breaches identified at the practice.
items.content: Patients of a dentist in Sydney's south are being urged to get tested for blood-borne viruses due to infection control breaches identified at the practice.The Chief Health Officer has advised current and former patients of Safuan Hasic, also known as Steven Hasic, who worked from a practice at 70 Victoria Avenue, Mortdale, to get tested for blood-borne viruses due to infection control breaches identified at his practice.Patients could have been exposed to hepatitis B, hepatitis C and HIV, due to poor cleaning and inadequate sterilisation of dental equipment.READ MORE: The simple $20 billion mistake nearly all of us are makingHowever health bosses said it's "low risk".Hasic's registration as a dental practitioner has been suspended by the Dental Council of NSW.NSW Health has also issued a closure order for the dental surgery in Mortdale.It said it has tracked down some patients and is contacting them.But it has issued a plea for others to take note. Director of South Eastern Sydney Local Health District's Public Health Unit, Dr Vicky Sheppeard, said while the potential risk of infection is low, blood-borne viruses can have serious health impacts."Any current or former patients of Mr Hasic should see their GP as soon as possible and ask to be tested for blood-borne viruses as a precautionary measure," Sheppeard said."Blood-borne viruses can be spread between clients on dental instruments where there isn't stringent infection control."People infected with blood-borne viruses may not show symptoms for many years, so it is important to be tested to see if there is silent infection."There are effective treatments for hepatitis B, hepatitis C and HIV."Patients who have had tests after their last visit with Hasic should check with their GP if more tests are needed, even if results were negative.NSW Health is working with the Dental Council of NSW and Health Care Complaints Commission to investigate.Sign up here to receive our daily newsletters and breaking news alerts, sent straight to your inbox.

ai_summary: A Sydney dentist is facing claims of infection control breaches.
Patients of the dentist are urged to get tested for viruses.
Safuan Hasic, also known as Steven Hasic, is barred from practice.
The breaches occurred at his Mortdale dentistry practice.
The breaches raise concerns about patient safety.
